title: 110_s2455
content:
The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" may be cited as the short title. Additional emergency CDBG funding is addressed in the Act. The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" authorizes $1 billion for foreclosure-related assistance to States, cities, and counties. Funds can be used for housing foreclosure impacts and rental assistance, but not for direct homeowner assistance. The "Community Foreclosure Assistance Act of 2007" authorizes $1 billion for foreclosure-related assistance to States, cities, and counties. Funds can be used for housing foreclosure impacts and rental assistance, but not for direct homeowner assistance. Funds may be provided to a certified housing counseling service for foreclosure prevention purposes, including refinancing assistance and loans. SEC. 3. INCREASED PUBLIC SERVICES REQUIREMENT CAP.

This Act increases the public services requirement cap from 15% to 25% for all funds provided under this Act.

SEC. 4. LOW AND MODERATE INCOME REQUIREMENT.

At least 50% of the funds under this Act must primarily benefit low- and moderate-income individuals. SEC. 5. PLANS AND REPORTS.

    States, metropolitan cities, or urban counties must submit a comprehensive plan for fund usage and quarterly reports to the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development has the authority to waive certain provisions of statutes or regulations to facilitate the use of funds by States, metropolitan cities, or urban counties, except for requirements related to fair housing, nondiscrimination, labor standards, and the environment. Waivers may be granted if a compelling need is demonstrated. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may waive public service requirements upon request if a compelling need is shown. Any waiver granted must be published in the Federal Register at least 5 days before taking effect and must be reviewed and reauthorized every 2 years. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development may waive public service requirements if a compelling need is shown. The waiver must be reviewed and reauthorized every 2 years. The Secretary must notify the Committees on Appropriations of any waiver granted or denied at least 5 days before it takes effect. SEC. 7. Noncompliance with community development requirements under this Act will be subject to the provisions of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1974. SEC. 8. The Comptroller General will conduct an audit of all funds appropriated under this Act and submit a report to the Senate and House Committees. SEC. 9. Reports will be required as part of the oversight process. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development must provide quarterly reports to the Senate and House Committees on the use of funds, including the number of households receiving counseling and rental assistance, outcomes of assistance activities, certified housing counseling services, steps taken to prevent fraud and abuse.
